Author: zemaj
Content:
Phew, back up. Although that the fact that it was possible to have the entire network go down is quite worrying.

S3 actually has an SLA; http://aws.amazon.com/s3-sla If I'm reading that right, if S3 is completely down for more than about 40 mins in Feb (which it was - about 90 mins by my count) then we should get a 10% discount for this month. Is that right?

Author: xirium
Content: Bummer. Would anyone like backup virtual hosting on our physical servers?

Content: I'm willing to try out 8aweek for the simple reason is if I'm doing work, I'm running Linux. I liked RescueTime, for the little that I experimented with it, but when I'm running Windows I'm usually just messing about.

Author: davidw
Content:
What he seems to mean is 'prevents many people from buying homes and having children', which I think is difficult to argue with. Obviously people buy those houses, but they probably aren't 'average middle class american' types, either.

One of the reasons I was happy to return to Italy in 2000 was that most towns there seem to have a mix of young and old, rich and poor that seemed much more real to me than San Francisco, which especially in those days was like living on another planet in terms of how weird it had gotten with all the money and craziness.

Author: edw519
Content: Reminds me of a college campus which did a major construction project for which the architects never included sidewalks because they didn't want to try to predict usage.  They waited 6 months and laid the sidewalks over the well worn paths in the grass.  Brilliant.

Author: ptm
Title: Massive S3 outage
Content:
Massive S3 outage. Seems to affect other AWS services (SDB, SQS) as well.

Other AWS services are down too ...\nEC2 http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=19715&tstart=0\nSQS http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=19713&tstart=0

Author: edw519
Content:
"dealing with it will be a big business"

Which may open up opportunities for the next round of startups: Workarounds to avoid HR mandated implementations of RescueTime and 8aweek.

In all my visits to client sites in the past 5 years, I would safely venture that 50% of all the time (that I've observed) spent by office workers is spent surfing the internet. I don't know why. Maybe they're bored. Maybe they don't have enough to do. Maybe they don't care. Maybe they lack guidance and direction (my guess).

I've often said that someone should develop a service that feeds selected content to a browser and looks exactly like outlook. The next killer app for bored workers and their PHBs. Would also save health care costs associated with sore fingers from "alt-tabbing" whenever the boss walks by.
